questions.text: A 42-year-old African American woman presents with visual disturbances. Eye examination reveals vitreous cells, snowball opacities, and candle wax drippings. Which type of uveitis is seen in the underlying disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Panuveitis

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests ocular sarcoidosis (granulomatous panuveitis).

 

Ocular Sarcoidosis Overview:
 

  • Disease Characteristics:
    • Granulomatous, multi-system disease with unknown cause
    • Non-caseating epithelioid cell granulomas
    • Common in young adults (20-50 years), more frequent in women and individuals of African descent

 

  • Common Presentations:
    • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
    • Pulmonary infiltration
    • Skin and eye lesions

 

  • Ocular Lesions:
    • Occur in 20-50% of cases
    • Types: Sarcoid uveitis, conjunctival lesions, lacrimal gland involvement

 

Sarcoid Uveitis

  • Prevalence: Accounts for 2% of uveitis cases
  • Types and Signs: Sarcoidosis is associated with Panuveitis

Type of Uveitis

Signs

Anterior (Option A)

Granulomatous iridocyclitis, iris nodules, large mutton fat KPs, anterior chamber cells and flare, posterior synechiae

Intermediate

Vitreous cells, snowball opacities, snowbanking

Posterior (Option C)

Choroidal and retinal granulomas, cystoid macular edema, periphlebitis retinae with candle wax droppings appearance

Peripheral Multifocal Chorioretinitis (Option D)

Small, punched-out atrophic spots, highly suggestive of sarcoidosis

Uveoparotid Fever (Heerfordt’s Syndrome)

Bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, painful parotid gland enlargement, cranial nerve palsies, skin rashes, fever, malaise

 

  • Complications:
    • Complicated cataract
    • Inflammatory glaucoma
    • Cystoid macular edema

 

Other Ocular Lesions

  • Conjunctival Lesions:
    • Sarcoid nodules
    • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca

 

  • Lacrimal Glands:
    • Enlargement can lead to Mickulicz’s syndrome (with diffuse salivary gland swelling)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can cause panuveitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)All of the above

 

Explanation:

Panuveitis can be caused by various systemic and ocular conditions, including VKH syndrome, Sympathetic Ophthalmia, and Sarcoidosis.

 

Causes of Panuveitis:

 

Autoimmune

Infectious
  • Sarcoidosis.
  • Birdshot retinochoroidopathy.
  • Sympathetic ophthalia.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa.
  • Lens-induced.
  • Infections (syphilis, TB, HSV/VZV, toxoplasmosis, cryptococcosis).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with vision loss in his right eye following a traumatic injury that resulted in a penetrating ocular wound two months ago. Recently, he has developed redness, photophobia, and decreased vision in his left eye as well. On examination, both eyes show signs of bilateral granulomatous uveitis. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Type I hypersensitivity reaction to lens proteins
Direct bacterial infection spreading from the injured eye
Immune complex deposition in the retinal vasculature

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Delayed hypersensitivity reaction to melanocytes

 

Explanation:

The patient is likely experiencing sympathetic ophthalmia, a condition characterized by bilateral granulomatous uveitis following trauma to one eye. The pathogenesis involves a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (T-cell mediated) to tyrosinase peptide antigens or melanocytes, leading to non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation in both eyes.

 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO)

Definition

Bilateral, granulomatous, panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma where uveal prolapse may have been a feature of the trauma

Etiology and pathogenesis
  • Trauma to one eye (exciting eye) — 2 weeks to 3 months — Uveitis in the uninjured eye (sympathizing eye).
  • T-cell mediated autoimmune hypersensitivity reaction to Retinal S antigen. (Option B)
  • Maximum risk upon injury to the ciliary body.

Histopathology
  • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the choroid.
  • Scattered aggregates of epithelioid cells are seen, many of which contain fine granules of melanin.
  • Dalen–Fuchs nodules - granulomas located between Bruch membrane and the RPE (also seen in VKH syndrome)

Clinical features
  • The exciting eye is frequently red and irritable.
  • The sympathizing eye develops irritation, blurred vision, photophobia and loss of accommodation causing difficulty in near vision (first symptom)
  • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, which may be mild or severe and is usually granulomatous

Investigations
  • Fundus exam: Dalen–Fuchs nodules, Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis and optic disc swelling.
  • As inflammation settles, residual chorioretinal scarring may confer a ‘sunset glow’ appearance similar to VKH.
  • B-scan ultrasonography: Choroidal thickening and retinal detachment

Treatment
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye within 10 to 14 days of the injury is effective in preventing or reducing the severity of SO
  • Steroids are the basis of initial treatment. Intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to response. Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics may be given

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) disease, Fundus examination shows the following findings. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Convalescent phase

 

Explanation:

The image shown is of Sunset Glow Fundus in the convalescent Phase of Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada Disease. The fundus has a slightly reddish appearance, mainly due to the disappearance of melanocytes in the choroid.

 

Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) Syndrome

Definition

Idiopathic multisystem autoimmune disease featuring inflammation of melanocyte-containing tissues such as the uvea, ear, and meninges.

Etiology
  • Idiopathic.
  • HLA associations: HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4.

Classification
  • Vogt–Koyanagi disease: Skin changes and anterior uveitis.
  • Harada disease: Neurological features and exudative retinal detachments.

Clinical features

Clinically, the disease is categorized into four phases:

  1. Prodromal phase (lasts for a few days): Neurological (meningitis, cranial nerve paresis) and auditory manifestations (tinnitus, vertigo and deafness).
  2. Acute uveitic phase: Bilateral granulomatous anterior and multifocal posterior uveitis with diffuse choroidal infiltration, vitritis, papillitis and exudative retinal detachments. Dalen–Fuchs nodules can be seen in this phase.
  3. Convalescent phase (follows several weeks later): Localized alopecia, poliosis and vitiligo, depigmented fundus appearance (‘sunset glow’ fundus) and depigmented limbal lesions (Sugiura sign). (Option C)
  4. Chronic recurrent phase: smouldering anterior uveitis with exacerbations

Investigations
  • Lumbar puncture: CSF shows a transient lymphocytic pleocytosis and melanin-containing macrophages.
  • Fundus Autofluorescence (FAF): Areas of serous detachment.
  • Ultrasonography: Diffuse choroidal thickening.
  • FA (Fluorescein Angiography) of the acute phase shows multifocal hyperfluorescent dots at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • OCT: Quantification of subretinal fluid.
  • ICGA: For monitoring

Complications and Prognosis

Ocular complications include:

  • Choroidal neovascularization
  • Subretinal fibrosis
  • Preretinal and disc new vessels
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Cataract
  • Glaucoma

Neurological and auditory manifestations tend to resolve but skin, lash and hair changes usually persist.

Treatment
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy (500–1000 mg/day).
  • High-dose (1–2 mg/kg/day) oral prednisolone, tapered over 3–6 months.
  • Topical steroids and cycloplegics are used for anterior uveitis.
  • Steroid-resistant patients may require immunosuppressives or biological blockers such as infliximab

Prodromal phase (Option A): Incorrect because this phase shows systemic symptoms without ocular fundus changes.

Uveitic phase (Option B): Incorrect because this phase shows active inflammation and serous retinal detachments, not depigmentation.

Recurrent phase (Option D): Incorrect because this phase has repeated anterior segment inflammation, not the classic sunset glow fundus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with progressively worsening blurry vision, eye pain, and redness in the right eye. Examination reveals restricted eye movement, and fundoscopic evaluation identifies a well-defined cystic lesion in the vitreous humor, accompanied by surrounding inflammation. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ocular cysticercosis

 

Explanation:

The presence of a well-defined cystic lesion in the vitreous humor with surrounding inflammation, along with restricted eye movement, is characteristic of ocular cysticercosis, caused by the larval stage of Taenia solium. Inflammation occurs mainly due to the release of toxins from the dead cysts.


 

Ocular cysticercosis

Definition

Infestation caused by Cysticercus cellulosae, the larval form of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium.

Pathophysiology

Humans ingest eggs of T. solium, leading to larvae formation (cysticercus) in various tissues.

Inflammation is triggered by antigens released from dead larvae, leading to tissue damage.

It is not contracted by eating undercooked pork.

Clinical Features

Systemic Involvement: Larvae can infest the CNS (neurocysticercosis), muscles, lungs, and subcutaneous tissues. Neurological manifestations include seizures and headaches.

Eye involvement:

  • Orbit and adnexal cysticercosis:
    • The extraocular muscles (superior rectus- most common) form is the most common type of orbital and adnexal cysticercosis.
    • Presents as periocular swelling, proptosis, ptosis, pain, diplopia, restriction of ocular motility, strabismus, decreased vision, lid edema and orbital cellulitis.
  • Ocular cysticercosis:
    • Intraocular cysticercosis can involve either the anterior or the posterior segment (more common).
    • Presents as blurring of vision, uveitis, vitritis, scotoma, and photopsia.

Diagnosis

B-scan Ultrasound: Diagnostic for intraocular cysticercosis; scolex within the cyst can be identified.

Serology: Detection of anti-cysticercus antibodies via ELISA.

Ophthalmic Examination: Identification of cysts in the AC or vitreous, signs of inflammation or retinal detachment.

Treatment

Ocular cysticercosis:

Surgical Treatment: Early removal of cysts via pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) or transscleral approach depending on cyst location.

Steroids: Systemic corticosteroids are used to control inflammation post-surgery.

Medical Management: Albendazole and corticosteroids are used for systemic infestation but with caution in intraocular cases to avoid severe inflammatory reactions caused by dying cysts.

 

Occular Toxoplasmosis (Option A): Fundoscopy shows focal necrotizing retinitis surrounded by a distinctive “headlight in the fog” appearance.

 

Endophthalmitis (Option B): It is usually associated with post-surgical infection, trauma, or endogenous spread. It presents with diffuse inflammation, hypopyon, and vitritis, not a well-defined cystic lesion.


Posterior uveitis due to TB (Option D): Tubercular uveitis often presents with granulomas, choroiditis, or vasculitis rather than a single cystic lesion with inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following ocular conditions is most commonly associated with a positive Amsler sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Fuchs heterochromatic uveitis

 

Explanation:

Amsler sign (aka Amsler-Verrey sign) is commonly seen in Fuchs heterochromic uveitis (FHU). It is characterized by hemorrhage in the anterior chamber after anterior chamber paracentesis or entry with a blade during anterior segment surgeries

 

Fuchs heterochromatic uveitis:

Non-granulomatous anterior uveitis

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Typically unilateral
  • Atypical anterior uveitis
  • Posterior uveitis- less common
  • Lightening of the colour of the affected iris- Heterochromia

 

  • Stellate keratic precipitates

 

  • Trabecular meshwork and iris display abnormal vessels with variable vitreous inflammation
  • Amsler sign (aka Amsler-Verrey sign)- hemorrhage in the anterior chamber after anterior chamber paracentesis or entry with the blade during anterior segment surgeries. Small twig-like vessels in the angle likely give rise to the Amsler sign.

 

  • Posterior subcapsular cataract

 

Treatment:

  • No role for cycloplegics or steroids in treatment.
  • For patients presenting with Cataract, IOL implantation is done

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a recent travel history to Africa presents with intense itching, skin nodules, and progressive vision loss. On examination, multiple palpable nodules are found on his skin, and there is early corneal clouding. Microfilariae are observed in a skin snip biopsy. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Ivermectin

 

Explanation:

The patient’s travel history, symptoms, and findings are consistent with onchocerciasis, caused by Onchocerca volvulus. The primary treatment for onchocerciasis is ivermectin, which kills the microfilariae and reduces the intensity of symptoms.

 

Onchocerciasis uveitis:

  • It is parasitic infestation- filarial nematode worm
  • Organism: Onchocerca volvulus
  • Vector- black fly
  • Also called river blindness

 

Pathophysiology:

  • Microfilariae are mobile and reach the eyes
  • Alive organisms cause little or no reaction
  • When dead, they produce focal inflammation with reactive destruction of the tissues.

Whereas in case of loa loa alive, adult worms produce a non inflammatory reaction.

 

Clinical manifestation: (Option D)

  • Sclerosing keratitis with anterior uveitis is common and leads to blindness
  • Oncosercoma.
  • Microfilariae is visualized in the anterior chamber
  • Acute papular onchodermatitis

Acute papular onchodermatitis

Microfilariae

Treatment:

  • Ivermectin- reduces the occurrence of blindness and skin disease (Option C)
  • Older treatments consisting of suramin and diethylcarbamazine are avoided (Option B)

 

Clindamycin + sulfadiazine (Option A): Used in Toxoplasmosis uveitis in combination or as part of quadruple therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old immunocompromised woman living with cats presents with decreased vision in her left eye. On examination, she has mild anterior uveitis with vitritis and the fundoscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Toxoplasma gondii

 

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis in this scenario is toxoplasmosis uveitis, which is caused by Toxoplasma gondii.
  • Fundoscopy shows focal necrotizing retinitis surrounded by a distinctive “headlight in the fog” appearance.
  • An immunocompromised person living with cats is a risk factor for toxoplasmosis.

 

Toxoplasmosis Uveitis:

  • It is a protozoan infestation.
  • Organism: Toxoplasma gondii
  • Definitive host - cats
  • Intermediate hosts - humans
  • Systemic lesions are more common in immunocompromised patients

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Most common cause of posterior uveitis and focal necrotizing retinitis (90% of cases)
  • Congenital
    • Inactive disease - Healed punched out heavily pigmented chorioretinal scars in the macular area

  • In active inflammation - “headlight in the fog” appearance due to intense vitritis
  • Acquired
    • Asymptomatic
    • Same as congenital
    • Punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis

 

Treatment:

  • Quadruple therapy: Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Clindamycin + Oral steroid
  • Steroid eye drops for anterior uveitis


 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option A): It causes viral retinitis. The characteristic picture is areas of necrosis with areas of vasculitis, retinal hemorrhages, and loss of fundal details giving a pizza pie appearance.


 

Candida albicans (Option B): It causes multifocal chorioretinitis. The characteristic picture is multiple small, round, whitish areas, which may be associated with areas of hemorrhages with pale centers (Roth's spots).

 

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option D): It causes fungal uveitis. The characteristic picture is choroidal neovascular membranes or disciform lesions at the macula with well-circumscribed peripheral chorioretinal scars in the absence of inflammatory signs in the aqueous and vitreous, and associated with peripapillary pigment epithelial atrophy.

questions.text:
Match bacterial uveitis in column A with corresponding clinical manifestation in column B


 


	
		
			
			Bacterial uveitis
			
			
			Clinical features
			
		
		
			
			1. Tubercular uveitis
			
			
			a. Iris pearls
			
		
		
			
			2. Leprotic uveitis
			
			
			b. Iris roceola
			
		
		
			
			3. Spirochetal uveitis
			
			
			c. Headlight in fog appearance
			
		
		
			
			d. Koeppe’s nodules
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b

Explanation:

 

Bacterial uveitis

Clinical features

1. Tubercular uveitis

d. Koeppe’s nodules

2. Leprotic uveitis

a. Iris pearls

3. Spirochetal uveitis

b. Iris roceola

 

Bacterial uveitis:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Syphilis
  • Leprosy

 

Tubercular uveitis:

  • Causes both anterior, intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis
  • Occurs as acute non-granulomatous iridocyclitis or granulomatous anterior uveitis
  • Granulomatous inflammation causes iris nodules in the pupillary margin (Koeppe nodule) or anterior mid-iris (Busacca nodule)
  • Exudative non-granulomatous type of iritis is probably allergic or immunoinflammatory in nature

Koeppe nodule

 

 

Treatment: Rifampicin, isoniazid, ethambutol and pyrazinamide

 

Spirochetal uveitis:

  • Organism: Treponema pallidum
  • Anterior uveitis:
    • It can present as granulomatous or non-granulomatous iritis typically in the secondary syphilis stage
    • Iris roseola - dilated iris vessels that develop into nodules
    • ‘Plastic’ iritis occurs in congenital syphilis and Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction


  • Posterior uveitis:
    • It occurs as disseminated, peripheral, or diffuse choroiditis.
  • Treatment: Systemic penicillin

 

Leprotic uveitis:

  • Organism-Mycobacterium leprae
  • It occurs as acute non granulomatous iritis or chronic granulomatous iritis
  • Chronic granulomatous iritis occurs due to direct invasion of the organismal and is characterized by 'iris pearls' near the pupillary margin in a necklace form.

  • Small pearls enlarge and coalesce to form large pearls
  • Other ocular manifestations: Conjunctivitis, episcleritis, exposure keratopathy because of involvement of the facial nerve, and neurotrophic keratopathy due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve
  • Treatment:
    • Dapsone
    • Rifampicin, ofloxacin, clofazimine and minocycline in combination with dapsone

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of Crohn’s disease presents with sudden onset of eye pain, redness, and blurred vision. Slit-lamp examination reveals fine, grey keratic precipitates, anterior chamber cells, and flare. Which type of uveitis is most consistent with her presentation?

choices.text: Both A and C are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)Non-granulomatous anterior uveitis

 

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is anterior uveitis, and the extraintestinal manifestations of IBD (Crohn’s disease here) include ocular complications. It is non-granulomatous type.

 

Uveitis in bowel disease:

  • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Most common in Crohn’s disease
    • Ocular complications-conjunctivitis, episcleritis, scleritis, marginal keratitis, anterior uveitis, retinitis, retinal vascular occlusive disease, optic neuritis, and orbital inflammatory disease.
    • Type: Non-granulomatous
  • Whipple’s disease

 

Posterior uveitis (Option C): Though IBD can also present with panuveitis or posterior uveitis, Presence of fine, grey keratic precipitates, anterior chamber cells, and flare on slit lamp examination is consistent with anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with HIV presents with vision loss and floaters. On examination, the patient has a CD4+ count of 40 cells/mm³. Fundoscopy reveals areas of necrosis with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CMV retinitis

 

Explanation:

  • CMV retinitis is common in immunocompromised patients (e.g., those with AIDS and low CD4+ counts).
  • Characterised by retinal necrosis with mild vitritis, and the sauce & cheese (AKA pizza pie) appearance in fundoscopic examination.

 

Viral Uveitis Overview

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO) (Option D)

  • Affects the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Anterior uveitis occurs in 40-50% of cases, usually within 2 weeks of skin rash onset.
  • Symptoms: mild iritis, vesicular rash on the nose, small KPs, mild aqueous flare, possible hemorrhagic hypopyon.
  • Complications: iris atrophy, secondary glaucoma, complicated cataracts, Acute Retinal Necrosis

 

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) (Option B)

  • Often linked with keratitis.
  • May present with dendritic or geographical corneal ulcers, or disciform keratitis.
  • Anterior uveitis can occur independently, presenting as mild non-granulomatous iridocyclitis due to hypersensitivity.

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option C)

  • Common in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., AIDS, chemotherapy).
  • Prevalence: 40% in AIDS patients.
  • Occurs with CD4+ counts <50 cells/mm³.
  • HAART has reduced CMV retinitis incidence.
  • Symptoms: may be asymptomatic, or cause decreased vision and floaters.
  • The characteristic appearance is of one or two areas of dense white retinal infiltration associated prominently with flame-shaped retinal haemorrhages (‘pizza pie’ or ‘Margherita pizza’), beginning peripherally (centrally in 10%) and extending along the course of the vascular arcades.

 

Toxoplasmosis (Option A)

  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii
  • Toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients may be acquired or result from reactivation of pre-existing disease
  • Symptoms: Unilateral acute or subacute onset of floaters, blurring and photophobia.
  • Features:
    • Fluffy white retinitis or retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar (‘satellite lesion’).
    • ‘Headlight in the fog’ is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through vitritis.

 

Additional Notes

  • Viral uveitis may be linked to bacterial uveitis and other infections such as chikungunya, dengue, West Nile virus, and rubella.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the uveal tract is false?

choices.text: The choroid connects anteriorly to the iris via the ciliary body.
The ciliary body contains both radial and circular smooth muscle fibers.
The posterior layer of the iris is continuous with the ciliary body
The constrictor pupillae muscle is controlled by sympathetic nerves.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)The constrictor pupillae muscle is controlled by sympathetic nerves.

 

Explanation:

The constrictor pupillae muscle is controlled by parasympathetic nerves, not sympathetic.

 

Middle Coat of the Eye (Uveal Tract)

  • General Characteristics:
    • Contains most of the blood vessels in the eye.
    • Contains melanin-producing cells.
    • Consists of three parts: choroid, ciliary body, and iris.

Choroid:

  • Origin: Neuroectoderm
  • Location: Posterior part of the vascular coat.
  • Characteristics:
    1. Lines the inner surface of the sclera.
    2. Connected anteriorly to the iris via the ciliary body. (Option A)
    3. Pierced posteriorly by the optic nerve.
  • Arteries: Short ciliary arteries from the optic nerve area.
  • Veins: Whorled arrangement forming 4-5 venae vorticosae, draining into ophthalmic veins.
  • Attachment: Firmly attached to the retina; nourishes photoreceptors by diffusion.
  • Layers:
    1. Suprachoroid Lamina (Lamina Fusca): Contains long posterior ciliary vessels and nerves.
    2. Vascular Lamina: Loose tissue with pigment cells, contains branches of ciliary arteries and veins forming venae vorticosae.
    3. Capillary Lamina: Fine capillary network nourishing retinal photoreceptors.
    4. Basal Lamina (Membrane of Bruch): Thin, transparent membrane

 

Ciliary Body:

  • Origin: Neuroectoderm
  • Location: Posterior to the corneoscleral junction, anterior to the ora serrata.
  • Ciliary Muscles: Smooth muscle with radial and circular fibers. (Option B)
  • Function: Focuses the lens for near vision by altering tension on the suspensory ligaments, allowing the lens to become more spherical.

 

Iris:

  • Origin: Neural crest cells and Neuroectoderm
  • Location: Between the cornea and lens, with a central opening called the pupil.
  • Attachment: Attached peripherally to the ciliary body; forms the iridocorneal angle (Option C).
  • Actions:
    • Constrictor Pupillae: Constricts the pupil.
    • Dilator Pupillae: Dilates the pupil.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with symptoms of recurrent bilateral eye inflammation, including redness, pain, and vision loss. He also has a history of frequent oral and genital ulcers and skin rashes. He is HLA-B51 positive. What would be the most appropriate approach for managing his uveitis?

choices.text: Start with systemic corticosteroids and consider long-term immunosuppressive therapy
Use of topical antibiotics for ocular symptoms
Prescription of oral antihistamines for symptom relief

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)Start with systemic corticosteroids and consider long-term immunosuppressive therapy

 

Explanation:

Systemic corticosteroids can provide initial relief for uveitis symptoms in Behcet’s disease, but for long-term management, immunosuppressive therapy is necessary due to the disease’s chronic nature and poor long-term prognosis with corticosteroids alone.

 

Behcet’s Disease

  • Nature: Idiopathic multisystem disease
  • Characteristics:
    • Recurrent non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Aphthous and genital ulcers
    • Erythema multiforme
  • Pathology: Obliterative vasculitis, likely due to circulating immune complexes
  • Demographics: Common in young men with HLA-B51

 

Uveitis in Behcet’s Disease

  • Presentation:
    • Bilateral and acute
    • Recurrent iridocyclitis with hypopyon
    • May include posterior uveitis, vitritis, periphlebitis retinae, and retinitis (white necrotic infiltrates)

Treatment

  • Corticosteroids: Effective initially but not long-term
  • Immunosuppressive Drugs: Methotrexate, azathioprine, cyclosporine for resistant or severe cases

 

Immediate initiation of antiviral therapy (Option B): Antiviral therapy is not appropriate as Behcet’s disease is not caused by viral infection.

Use of topical antibiotics for ocular symptoms (Option C): Topical antibiotics are not effective since the uveitis is due to an autoimmune process.

Prescription of oral antihistamines for symptom relief (Option D): Oral antihistamines are not suitable for treating the autoimmune-related uveitis in Behcet’s disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a recent history of urethritis and arthritis presents with eye symptoms. He is positive for HLA-B27. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical corticosteroids

 

Explanation:

Topical corticosteroids are the initial treatment for acute iridocyclitis.

 

Reiter's Syndrome and Uveitis

  • Characteristics: Reiter’s syndrome includes urethritis, arthritis, and conjunctivitis, often with iridocyclitis. Common in young men, especially those positive for HLA-B27.
  • Ocular Features:
    • Acute mucopurulent conjunctivitis, possibly with superficial punctate keratitis.
    • Acute, non-granulomatous iridocyclitis occurs in 20-30% of cases.
  • Treatment:
    • Iridocyclitis: Managed with topical, periocular, and systemic corticosteroids.
    • Post Venereal form (likely due to Chlamydia): Treated with systemic tetracycline (250 mg, four times daily for 10 days).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with unilateral eye pain, photophobia, and redness for the past five days. Slit-lamp examination reveals circumcorneal injection, anterior chamber cells and flare, and posterior synechiae. Despite initial treatment with topical corticosteroids and cycloplegics, his symptoms persist, and intraocular pressure (IOP) is found to be elevated.

Which of the following is the most likely complication of the condition he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)Secondary glaucoma

 

Explanation:

  • Secondary glaucoma is a known complication of anterior uveitis, often resulting from inflammatory trabeculitis, corticosteroid response, or synechial angle closure. In this case, the patient has posterior synechiae, which can lead to pupillary block and increased intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Chronic inflammation can also cause damage to the trabecular meshwork, leading to impaired aqueous outflow and secondary glaucoma.

 

Complication

Description

Additional Details

Complicated Cataract

Common in iridocyclitis, characterized by posterior subcapsular opacities with "polychromatic luster" and "bread-crumb" appearance.
  • Matures faster with posterior synechiae presence.

Secondary Glaucoma

Can occur early or late due to iridocyclitis.
  • Early: Usually Open-angle. Blockage of trabecular meshwork by exudates/inflammatory cells.
  • Late: Usually Closed. Pupillary block causes impaired aqueous humor flow.

Cyclitic Membrane

Late complication where exudates behind the lens become organized in acute plastic iridocyclitis.

  

Choroiditis

Long-standing iridocyclitis can lead to choroiditis due to the continuity of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid.

  

Retinal Complications

Includes cystoid macular edema, macular scar/hole, epiretinal membrane, exudative retinal detachment, secondary periphlebitis retinae, retinal scars, sub-retinal fibrosis.

  

Papillitis

Inflammation of the optic disc, seen in severe cases of iridocyclitis.

  

Band-shaped Keratopathy

Common in children with Still’s disease and chronic uveitis.

  

Phthisis Bulbi

Final stage of chronic uveitis where the eye becomes soft, shrunken, and atrophic.
  • Without Shrinkage: Globe shape intact, vision loss, cataractous lens, retinal detachment, raised IOP early.
  • With Shrinkage: Lowered IOP, collapsed anterior chamber, shrunken eyeball.
  • With Disorganization: Significant eyeball reduction, scleral thickening, possible intraocular ossification.

 

Retinal Detachment (Option A)

  • Retinal detachment is more commonly associated with posterior uveitis or severe panuveitis, where inflammatory damage to the retina and choroid leads to traction or exudative detachment.
  • Anterior uveitis typically does not cause retinal detachment unless it is part of a more widespread inflammatory process.

Vitreous Hemorrhage (Option C)

  • Vitreous hemorrhage occurs due to retinal neovascularization, trauma, or severe posterior uveitis.
  • Anterior uveitis mainly affects the anterior segment of the eye, and there is no mention of retinal or choroidal involvement in this patient.

Optic Neuritis (Option D)

  • Optic neuritis is typically associated with multiple sclerosis (MS), neuromyelitis optica (NMO), or infections, and it presents with retrobulbar pain and vision loss rather than the pain and photophobia seen in anterior uveitis.
  • Anterior uveitis alone does not usually cause optic nerve inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Posterior uveitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Iridocyclitis

 

Explanation:

Posterior uveitis is defined as the inflammation of the choroid and the retina. The components of posterior uveitis include the following,

  • Choroiditis
  • Retinitis
  • Retinal vasculitis
    • Periphlebitis - Venous sheathing
    • Periarteritis - Hemorrhages

 

Causes of Posterior Uveitis:
 

Category

Examples

Infectious Causes

Viruses: CMV, HSV, herpes zoster, rubella, measles

Bacteria: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Brucella spp., Borrelia burgdorferi, other gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria

Fungi: Candida spp., Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces spp., Cryptococcus neoformans, Aspergillus spp.

Parasites: Toxoplasma gondii, Toxocara spp., Onchocerca volvulus, Acanthamoeba spp.

Non-Infectious Causes

Autoimmune: Behçet's disease, VKH syndrome, SLE, Wegener's granulomatosis, sympathetic ophthalmia

Malignancy: Intraocular lymphoma, malignant melanoma, leukemia

Unknown Etiology: Sarcoidosis, serpiginous choroiditis, Birdshot chorioretinopathy, retinal pigmented epitheliopathy

 

Clinical Features of Posterior Uveitis

Type

Features

Symptoms

Defective Vision: Ranges from mild blurriness to severe vision loss

Photopsia: Flashes of light from retinal irritation

Floaters: Black spots or cobwebs due to vitreous debris

Metamorphopsia: Distorted vision, with straight lines appearing wavy

Scotoma: Blind spot or reduced vision area in the visual field

Signs

Vitreous Opacities: Fine or coarse opacities, "snowballs", or strands in the vitreous humor

Active Chorioretinal Lesions: Pale yellow or white, raised areas with blurred margins; possible retinal haziness and vasculitis 

Healed Chorioretinal Lesions: White, atrophic areas with choroidal thinning; black pigment clumping at edges 

 

Note: Posterior uveitis is typically painless, unlike anterior uveitis, which often presents with pain, redness, and photophobia.

questions.text: What is the 1st line of treatment in a 35 year old patient presenting with Intermediate uveitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Periocular injection of triamcinolone

 

Explanation:

The most appropriate initial treatment for intermediate uveitis, especially when it is idiopathic and presents with significant vitreous inflammation, is the periocular injection of triamcinolone. This approach targets inflammation locally with fewer systemic side effects compared to systemic steroids.

 

Intermediate Uveitis: Overview, Investigations, and Treatment

  • Intermediate uveitis is an inflammation affecting the pars plana, peripheral retina, choroid, and vitreous base, comprising 10% of all uveitis cases, and 20% in children.
  • It's bilateral in 80% of cases and equally affects both genders.
  • The cause is idiopathic in 85% of cases, typically occurring in the 2nd and 4th decades of life.
  • Known causes include tuberculosis, syphilis, sarcoidosis, Lyme disease, and multiple sclerosis.

 

Investigations

  • Slit-lamp examination: Detects subtle anterior segment signs like low-grade flare, cells in the aqueous humor, and keratic precipitates.
  • Indirect ophthalmoscopy: Visualizes the retina and vitreous, identifying snowball opacities, vitreous condensation, and snowbanking near the ora serrata.
  • Goldmann three-mirror examination: Detailed peripheral retina and pars plana examination for snowbanking.
  • Fluorescein angiography: Assesses retinal vessel leakage, especially in snowbanking or macular edema.
  • Systemic investigations: Blood tests, chest X-ray, and lumbar puncture to identify underlying conditions like sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, and multiple sclerosis.

 

Treatment (Kaplan's Modified 4-Step Protocol)

Step

Treatment

Details

1

Periocular & Systemic Steroids

Triamcinolone injection: 40 mg, 3 injections spaced 3 weeks apart.

Oral corticosteroids: Typically considered if periocular steroids are insufficient. Gradual tapering is done. (Option B)

2

Immunosuppressive Drugs

Agents: Cyclosporine, azathioprine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide.

Close monitoring due to potential side effects.

3

Cryotherapy/Indirect Laser Photocoagulation (Option D)

Cryotherapy: Controlled cold-induced injury. Used for snowbanking when less invasive treatments fail.

Laser photocoagulation: Focused light beam treatment.

4

Pars Plana Vitrectomy (Option A)

Surgery: For severe cases or complications (e.g., tractional retinal detachment). Removes vitreous gel, and clears debris.

 

Complications to Monitor

  • Cataract formation
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Band keratopathy
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment

Regular follow-up is essential to monitor and adjust treatment, minimizing complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with floaters and gradual deterioration of vision. On examination, there is anterior vitritis with white snowball-like exudates and mild peripheral periphlebitis. No other relevant history or clinical findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intermediate uveitis

 

Explanation:

The presence of floaters, anterior vitritis, and white snowball-like exudates near the ora serrata with mild peripheral periphlebitis are characteristic of intermediate uveitis (pars planitis).

 

Intermediate Uveitis: Causes and Features

 

Definition:
Intermediate uveitis, also known as pars planitis, primarily affects the pars plana of the ciliary body and the peripheral choroid. It mostly occurs in children and young adults, with a higher incidence in females.

 

Causes

  • Etiology: Nonspecific inflammation with an unknown cause.
  • Onset: Insidious

 

Features

Common Features

Less Frequent Features

Floaters

Macular edema

Vision deterioration due to anterior vitreous opacities

Papillitis or disc oedema

Minimal aqueous flare with occasional keratic precipitates

Retrolenticular cyclitic membranes

Anterior Vitritis

Vitreous hemorrhage

White snowball-like exudates near the ora serrata

Tractional retinal detachment (rare)

Mild peripheral periphlebitis

  

  • Snowball-like exudates may coalesce into a "snowbank" appearance.
  • 80% of cases do not require treatment.
  • Chronic cases may require corticosteroids; however, there is poor response to therapy.
  • Immunosuppressants are reserved for severe cases unresponsive to steroids.

 

Differential Diagnosis

  • CMV Retinitis: Typically presents with focal retinochoroiditis rather than the diffuse features seen in intermediate uveitis. (Option A)
  • Peripheral toxocariasis
  • Tuberculosis: Typically causes anterior uveitis. (Option B)
  • Lyme Uveitis: May cause uveitis but typically presents with more acute dermatological symptoms, and the ocular findings are not as specific to intermediate uveitis as in this case. More commonly seen in the relapsing-remitting type. (Option D)
  • Sarcoidosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with eye pain, redness, and a constricted pupil. During the examination, fine, grey deposits on the corneal endothelium are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in investigating and treating this condition?

choices.text: Perform a chest X-ray and initiate treatment with topical cycloplegics.
Order a serum ACE level and start treatment with non-steroidal voclosporin.
Conduct an HLA typing and begin treatment with topical prednisolone.
Arrange for an OCT scan and administer systemic interferon-alpha.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Conduct an HLA typing and begin treatment with topical prednisolone.

 

Explanation:

The findings are consistent with a case of anterior uveitis. HLA typing is important in identifying associated systemic conditions that may cause anterior uveitis, such as Behçet's disease or VKH syndrome. Topical prednisolone is a standard treatment for reducing inflammation in anterior uveitis.

 

Investigations for Anterior Uveitis:

Ocular Investigations:

  • USG-B-Scan: To assess the posterior segment of the eye for any abnormalities.
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): To evaluate the retinal and choroidal circulation and detect any leakage or abnormalities.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT)

Systemic Investigations:

  • Syphilis Tests:
    • VDRL
    • TPHA: Treponema pallidum Hemagglutination Assay.
  • Sarcoidosis:
    • Serum ACE Levels: Elevated in sarcoidosis.
    • Chest X-Ray: To identify any pulmonary involvement or sarcoidosis.
  • Mantoux Test / QuantiFERON Test: To detect tuberculosis infection.
  • X-Ray Spine: To check for ankylosing spondylitis or other spinal abnormalities.
  • HLA Typing:
    • HLA-B27: Associated with various types of arthritis, including ankylosing spondylitis.
    • HLA-B5 and HLA-B51: Associated with Behçet's disease.
    • HLA-DR4: Associated with VKH syndrome and sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Treatment for Anterior Uveitis:

  • Topical Steroids (Treatment of Choice):
    • Prednisolone: Commonly used for reducing inflammation.
    • Loteprednol: Less potential for increasing intraocular pressure.
  • Cycloplegics (Topical):
    • Rest the ciliary muscles to relieve pain.
    • Prevent and break posterior synechiae (adhesions of the iris to the lens).
    • Improve blood supply, leading to better healing.
  • Non-Steroidal Treatment:
    • Voclosporin: Part of the Luminate program, used as a non-steroidal option.
  • For Chronic or Vision-Threatening Uveitis:
    • Monoclonal Antibodies:
      • Adalimumab: TNF-alpha inhibitor, used for severe or chronic cases.
      • Infliximab: TNF-alpha inhibitor.
    • Interferon Alpha: An option for severe cases, helps modulate the immune response.

 

Perform a chest X-ray and initiate treatment with topical cycloplegics (Option A): While a chest X-ray can be useful for diagnosing sarcoidosis, it usually presents with mutton fat KP’s not fine ones. Cycloplegics are used to relieve pain and prevent synechiae but do not address inflammation directly.

Order a serum ACE level and start treatment with non-steroidal voclosporin (Option B): Serum ACE levels are specific for diagnosing sarcoidosis, and voclosporin is used for non-steroidal treatment but is not the first-line treatment.

Arrange for an OCT scan and administer systemic interferon alpha (Option D): OCT scans are useful for checking Cystoid Macular Edema. Systemic interferon alpha is used in severe, chronic cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a 1-week history of worsening eye pain and redness. On examination, a constricted pupil, a hazy anterior chamber, and deposits on the back of the cornea as shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterior Uveitis

 

Explanation:

  • Anterior uveitis is characterized by the presence of fine, grey keratic precipitates (KPs) on the corneal endothelium, a hazy anterior chamber (aqueous flare), and a constricted pupil.

 

Anterior Uveitis

Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

 

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle

  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Koeppe's Nodules

 

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil

 

  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

 

Herpes Simplex Keratitis (Option A):

  • Presents with dendritic corneal ulcers, not fine, grey keratic precipitates or a hazy anterior chamber.
  • It also usually does not involve a constricted pupil.

Conjunctivitis (Option B):

  • Does not cause keratic precipitates , hazy anterior chamber and a constricted pupil.

Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma (Option D):

  • Presents with a mid-dilated or fixed, mid-dilated pupil, severe pain, redness, and vision changes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with anterior uveitis. After a detailed evaluation, the ophthalmologist considers various systemic associations and possible masquerades for the condition. Which of the following conditions is a known systemic association with anterior uveitis, but not a masquerade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Behcet's Disease

 

Explanation:

Behcet's Disease is a known systemic association with anterior uveitis, characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, and uveitis.

Anterior uveitis, also known as iritis, is an inflammatory condition of the eye, including the iris and ciliary body.

 

Systemic Associations and Masquerades of Anterior Uveitis

  • Infectious Causes:
    • Herpes Infections: Varicella Zoster, Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
    • Tuberculosis (TB)
    • Syphilis
    • Leprosy

 

  • Non-Infectious Causes:
    • With Systemic Association:
      • Sarcoidosis
      • Behçet's Disease
      • HLA-B27 Associated Arthritis
      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) > Crohn's Disease
    • Without Systemic Association:
      • Drug-Induced: Pilocarpine, prostaglandin analogues

 

  • Masquerade Syndromes:
    • Definition: Conditions that mimic the symptoms of anterior uveitis but are not primarily inflammatory in nature.
    • Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Lymphomas
      • Anterior Segment Melanoma
      • Retinoblastoma (Option C)
      • Metastasis
    • Non-Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Intraocular Foreign Body (Option A)
      • Old Retinal Detachment
      • Pigment Dispersion Syndrome (Option D)
      • Coats' Disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the classification of uveitis based on the time of inflammatory activity is false?

choices.text: Acute uveitis is defined as having a duration of less than 3 months and typically has a sudden onset.
Chronic uveitis is classified as lasting more than 6 months without interruption.
Recurrent uveitis involves repeated episodes with periods of inactivity between them.
Remission in uveitis is defined as no inflammatory activity for 3 months or more.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chronic uveitis is classified as lasting more than 6 months without interruption.

 

Explanation:

Chronic uveitis is defined as uveitis that lasts more than 3 months, not 6 months.

 

Classification Based on Time of Inflammatory Activity

Acute Uveitis: (Option A)

  • Duration: < 3 months
  • Onset: Sudden

Chronic Uveitis:

  • Duration: > 3 months

Recurrent Uveitis:(Option C)

  • Characterized by repeated episodes
  • Includes periods of inactivity between episodes

Remission:

  • No inflammatory activity for ≥ 3 months (Option D)
